revised_title: Histological and Electrical Changes in the Cochlea of the Cat Following VIIIth Nerve Section
tldr: The authors conducted experiments on cats to study the histological and electrical changes in the cochlea after sectioning the VIIIth nerve. They found that the hair-cell theory of the Wever and Bray phenomenon is not valid, and the membrane theory provides a better explanation for the cochlear component of the phenomenon. The results also suggest that following nerve section, a basal meningitis occurs, leading to serous labyrinthitis and potential chronic obstruction to the flow of perilymph.
